title: HPHT Limited Kick Tolerance Decision
question: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, you are drilling the HPHT reservoir section at {{currentSection.settingDepth.tvd}} {{currentSection.settingDepth.unit}} TVD. Kick tolerance is only {{kickTolerance.ktValue}} bbls at {{kickTolerance.influxIntensity}} ppg influx intensity. You take a {{scenario.kickVolume}} bbl kick with SIDPP of {{scenario.sidpp}} psi. Given the limited kick tolerance, what is the PRIMARY concern and appropriate response?

conditions.primaryConcern: Gas expansion during circulation may still approach shoe limits
conditions.response: Proceed with kill but closely monitor casing pressure vs MAASP. Consider Driller's Method to get influx out quickly.

conditions.primaryConcern: High risk of exceeding formation strength at shoe during circulation
conditions.response: Proceed cautiously. May need to bullhead or use volumetric method if casing pressure approaches MAASP. Have contingencies ready.

conditions.primaryConcern: Kick volume already at or exceeds kick tolerance - conventional circulation may fracture shoe
conditions.response: Conventional kill methods may not be viable. Consider bullheading, volumetric control, or other alternative methods. This is an emergency.

feedback.manageable: With {{scenario.kickVolume}} bbls (less than half the {{kickTolerance.ktValue}} bbl kick tolerance), conventional kill should work but requires vigilant monitoring. Gas expansion is still significant in deep HPHT wells.
feedback.critical: With {{scenario.kickVolume}} bbls approaching the {{kickTolerance.ktValue}} bbl limit, you have minimal margin. Prepare alternative kill methods and be ready to switch if casing pressure trends toward MAASP.
feedback.emergency: At {{scenario.kickVolume}} bbls, you've met or exceeded kick tolerance. Circulating this out conventionally will likely fracture the shoe, causing underground blowout. This requires supervisor-level decision making and possibly alternative methods.

contextualTip: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, the limited kick tolerance in the reservoir section is why the DOP mandates 'highest level well control alertness.' Prevention through early kick detection is far better than managing a kick that exceeds your tolerance.
advancedNote: L4 supervisors must pre-plan responses for kicks at or near tolerance limits. Know your bullhead rates, volumetric procedures, and when to escalate to shore-based well control specialists.
